Thanks for your effort. MIKY.

Your encodes do need a bit more bitrate, but also some higher quality settings in HandBrake.

May I suggest that for bitrates below 2500 Kbps to also reduce resolution? Some might say, whoa-not-HD, but @ 1024 you will get a better quality and for an iPad2 or mini is just right.

AAC 5.1 is not very compatible (not many stand-alone players can play AAC above stereo 2.0), and AC3 works best in a MKV.

To increase Quality don't encode with CRF, do a 2pass (even if it take much longer). Decide on a good size, according to duration (888 MB for a 50-55 min episode is ok). Doing 2pass, will let the encoder reduce and increase bitrate according to the complexity of the scene and that can vary a lot between a dark, static forest and a speed action scene with plenty of light and particles. Using CRF will adjust bitrate without knowledge of the WHOLE episode/movie.

Also a deblock of -1:-1 is recommended for something that was already encoded from BluRay, even -2 if there's lots of detail (and in medieval dark movies it is!)

Try this:
ref=3 / deblock=1:-1:-1 / analyse=0x3:0x133 / me=umh / subme=6 / psy=1 / psy_rd=1.00:0.00 / mixed_ref=1 / me_range=16 / chroma_me=1 / trellis=1 / 8x8dct=1

Or in HandBrake / Advanced Tab:

Reference Frame = 3
Max B-Frames = 3
CABAC = ON
8x8 Transform = ON
Weighted P-Frames = ON
Pyramidal B-Frames = Normal

Adaptive B-Frames = Fast
Adaptve Direct Mode = Spatial
Motion Estimation Method = UMH (Uneven Multi-Hexagon)
Subpixel Motion Estimation = 6 (RD in I/P-frames)
Motion Estimation Range = 16

Trellis = Encode Only

---
Motion estimation is what matters most for quality, but also takes more time, as you increase this settings. Adding more Re-Frames and B-Frames helps less and if you want to gain a bit of time / encode. 

---
Using this settings (1024 @ 2pass) on my Core2Duo 6550 (3.1 GHz) a 50 min episode encodes in 1.5 hours. Unfortunatelly HandBrake is only optimized for NVIDIA, so it does not use my Radeon 5850 at all :(

---
Your encode uses:

cabac=1 / ref=1 / deblock=1:0:0 / analyse=0x3:0x113 / me=hex / subme=2 / psy=1 / psy_rd=1.00:0.00 / mixed_ref=0 / me_range=16 / chroma_me=1 / trellis=0 / 8x8dct=1

ref=1 :: Only 1 Reference Fame ?? (makes blocky artefacts visible)
me=hex :: A weak (fast) Motion Estimation that also increases ghosting and blockyness
subme=2 :: worse than a xvid encode, why bother with x264 ?
trellis=0 :: of course is not needed for subme=2 but for higher functions (6 and up) helps A LOT with compression.

@ kside

Wow haha thanks for all that detailed info.  I realize that my encodes are not as good as they could be, but I only have a 2+ year-old dual-core laptop (2.4ghz) with 4gb of ram.  I also am pretty impatient, so that is also why I do not do the more "legit" uploads like you are suggesting. However, I will definitely keep this in mind for the future.  Man, you know your encoding stuff!  So, yeah I mean I know changing all those high profile settings will result in higher quality, but in the end it really comes down to bitrate.  That is interesting to know about CRF.  And, again, I know that 2-pass results in higher quality, but to me, time is of the essence.  I will have to be more patient in the future and do some more "legit" encoding.  Thanks again!
